awd_titl_txt: Dark Matter and Disk-Halo Interaction in the Milky Way
awd_abstract_narration:
When we look at the Universe, we see stars, planets, black holes, neutron stars, and the gas and dust between them.  All of this is made from normal matter.  Astronomers believe that for every pound of normal matter, there are five or six pounds of something called dark matter.  We only know about dark matter by its gravitational attraction to the normal matter that we see. 

The investigators seek to discover where that dark matter is in our own Milky Way galaxy.  If investigators can find spots were the stars in the Milky Way are jostled in predicted ways, they will learn how dark matter interacts with regular matter.  To find the location of dark matter, the investigators will study the motions of stars from smaller galaxies that are falling into the Milky Way, and the motions in the Milky Way disk, which is the part of our galaxy that includes the spiral arms.  These stars will be pulled towards the dark matter, which will make it possible for identify the dark matter location and concentration.

In addition to providing researchers with constraints on dark matter in the Universe, the investigators will directly contribute to education at all levels.  Graduate and undergraduate students will learn how to conduct research.  They will connect with the public through open houses at the campus observatory, by helping to train high school students who will staff open houses at a local science museum, and by interacting with more than 15,000 people around the world who voluntarily contribute their computers to help the researchers do calculations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the motions of stars in the Milky Way galaxy, to better understand our galaxy's history as well as the spatial distribution of dark matter. Though dark matter particles have never been discovered, they provide the majority of the gravitational force that governs the motions of stars.

One PhD student made the first measurement of the dark matter content of a dwarf galaxy that no longer exists. As dwarf galaxies fall into the Milky Way, they are ripped apart by gravitational forces to form "tidal streams" of stars that are spread across the sky. The student simulated a multitude of different dwarf galaxies falling into a Milky Way-like galaxy until the same pattern of stars that are observed in a tidal stream called the Orphan-Chenab Stream (OCS) was created. From this, the mass and shape of both the stars and the dark matter in the original dwarf galaxy was estimated. In order to run the hundreds of thousands of simulations required to optimize the dwarf galaxy properties, volunteered computers from all over the world were used. The infrastructure that runs astronomical optimizations on volunteer computers is called MilkyWay@home. This powerful supercomputer and communications with the volunteers was primarily supported by this grant. The small galaxy that became the OCS was found to have ten times less dark matter than expected, though this result needs to be confirmed.

Another PhD student challenged the popular belief that the stars in the outer part of the Milky Way (the stellar halo) came from a single dwarf galaxy that collided with our galaxy 10 billion years ago. Their results show that stars from multiple infalling dwarf galaxies contribute to the stellar halo, and that a large fraction of these stars are from collisions that happened much more recently than 10 billion years. The evidence includes:

(1) Shells of stars were found for the first time in the Milky Way galaxy. Shells are umbrella-shaped groups of stars that are all about the same distance from the center of a large galaxy, and form when a small galaxy is ripped apart very close to the center of the larger galaxy. The shells identified by this grant come from an event named the Virgo Radial Merger (VRM). A new method was developed to use the positions of the stars in shells to determine how long ago the small galaxy collided with the center of the Milky Way. Applying this method, it was shown that the VRM must have happened less than 5 billion years ago, and possibly less than 1 billion years ago. This is shows that a significant fraction of the stellar halo was formed much less than 10 billion years ago.

(2) Additionally, it was found that the stellar halo includes different groups of stars that have different motions and different chemical compositions. When the stars from a small galaxy are spread across the Milky Way halo, they still retain some of the motion and the chemical properties of the original small galaxy. Using the velocities and the amounts of certain elements in local halo stars, it was found that the halo contains the remains of at least four dwarf galaxy mergers, and likely more than that.

In addition to the paper on the progenitor of the OCS and four papers on the VRM, the project supported three papers on the gravitational impact that small galaxies near the Milky Way have on stars in the Milky Way disk, two papers on the stars that are intermediate between the disk and the stellar halo, and two papers on small groups of stars in the stellar halo. In all, this project produced 12 academic papers that were published in high-profile refereed journals. Four of the papers were written by PhD students who were primarily supported by this grant. Three papers were first-authored by undergraduate students who worked with the PI.

The project contributed substantially to workforce development, including primary support for two PhD theses, training of 3 additional PhD students and 6 MS students, meaningful research experiences for 51 undergraduates (most of whom were doing research for the first time), and research exposure for four high school students. Nine of the students won department-wide research-related awards for their research, and eight students won Rensselaer’s Founders Award for research, scholarship, and community activities. A high school student won the Dudley Observatory award at the 2020 Regeneron Greater Capital Region Science and Engineering Fair.

All of the software used for the N-body simulations was made public, including MilkyWay@home N-body Lite, pre-compiled version of our N-body code for simulating tidal streams. A Python package (mwahpy) that provides useful tools for working with MilkyWay@home was also made publicly available.

Results were disseminated to the public on YouTube and in multiple press releases, and to other astronomers through conference presentations.
